security_audit.summary: Prompt-based skill providing Python code examples for legitimate PDF processing tasks. No executable code, network calls, or suspicious patterns detected. All capabilities align with stated purpose.

content.value_statement: PDF documents contain valuable data but are difficult to process programmatically. This skill provides code patterns to extract text, tables, and form data from PDFs using Python libraries like pdfplumber and pypdf.
actual_capabilities: Extract text content from PDF pages using pdfplumber
Detect and extract tables from PDF documents automatically
Fill PDF form fields with values programmatically
Merge multiple PDF files into a single document
Split PDFs to extract specific pages or page ranges
Convert PDFs to images and perform OCR on scanned documents
limitations: Cannot extract text from scanned PDFs without OCR (requires pytesseract)
Processing large PDFs may require memory optimization
Complex multi-layer PDFs may have limited extraction accuracy
Some encrypted or password-protected PDFs require decryption first

best_practices: Test extraction on sample files before processing large batches
Validate extracted data matches the original PDF visually
Handle exceptions gracefully for corrupted or password-protected files
anti_patterns: Assuming all PDFs contain extractable text (scanned images need OCR)
Processing entire documents when only specific pages are needed
Skipping error handling for file access or format issues

faq.question: What PDF libraries does this skill support?
faq.answer: pdfplumber for text/table extraction, pypdf for manipulation, pdf2image for conversion, pytesseract for OCR.

faq.question: Can I extract text from scanned PDFs?
faq.answer: Yes, but you need pytesseract and Tesseract OCR installed. Regular pdfplumber cannot read scanned images.

faq.question: What formats can I export extracted data to?
faq.answer: Plain text, CSV, JSON, or directly to databases using Python libraries like pandas.

faq.question: Is my data safe when processing PDFs?
faq.answer: Yes, all processing happens locally on your machine. No data is sent to external services.

faq.question: Why does extraction fail on some PDFs?
faq.answer: Common causes: scanned images (needs OCR), password protection, corrupted files, or non-standard encoding.

faq.question: How does this compare to commercial PDF tools?
faq.answer: This provides code-based automation. Commercial tools offer GUIs but require manual steps for each document.
